aurlit
the Auditor-General shall satisfy himself that the moneys
expended by each statutory corporation, public company,
Department or private institution have been applied to the
purposes for which they were appropriated.
(2) The Auditor-General shall determine the scope and
extent of the examination or inspection of the accounts of
each statutory corporation, public company, Department or
private institution which he considers desirable to achieve the
/
purposes specified in subsection ( 1 ).
(3) In the performance of his duties under subsections (l)
and (2), the Auditor-General shall not be subject to the direction
or control of any other person or authority.
Spe-010.I 5. (1) Whenever the Auditor-General has reason to believe
and that delay in reporting serious irregularities in the expenditure
interim
of public funds through his annual report may occasion financial
audit
report• loss to the Government or prejudice effective financial control,
he shalJ forthwith prepare such special, interim or other audit
report relating to audit investigation into such serious irregulari­
ties as he considers necessary to prevent or reduce any financial
loss to the Government.
(2) The Auc:Litor-General shall, as soon as practicable, submit
the special, interim or other audit report mentioned in sub­
section (1) to the President who shall, not later than seven
days after the first sitting of the National Assembly next after
the receipt of such report, cause it to be laid before the
Assembly; and if the President makes default in laying the
report before the Assembly, the Auc:Litor-General shall submit
the report to the Speaker of the Assembly, or, if the office of
Speaker is vacant or if the Speaker is for any reason unable to
perform the functions of his office, to the Deputy Speaker,
who shall cause it to be laid before the Assembly.

7.( 1I)n the performance of his duties under this Act, the Powers of
Auditor•
Auditor-General and any public officer, agent or specialist General
consultant authorised by him shall have-
(a) access to all books, records, returns, reports and other
documents relating to the accounts of any statutory
corporation, public company, Department or private
institution under audit examination or inspection;
(b) access at any reasonable time of the day to the premises
of any statutory corporation, public company,
Department or private institution under audit
examination or inspection;
(c) power to call for any relevant information from persons
responsible for the financial administration of any
statutory corporation, public company, Department
or private institution under audit examination or
inspection.
(2) Notwithstanding anything contained in subsection (1),
the Auditor-General shall not authorise any agent or specialist
consultant-
(a) to havo access to any books, records, retu.rns, reports or
other documents, to enter upon any premises, of

Security Intelligence Service; or
(/J) to have access to any books, records, returns, reports
or other documents, or to enter upon any premises
other than those mentioned in paragraph (a), if such
access or entry is likely to-
(i) prejudice the security, defence or international
relations of the Republic or the investigation
or detection of offences; or
(ii) involve the disclosure of any matters or deli­
berations of a secret or confidential nature of
the Central Committee or the Cabinet or any
sub-committee of the Central Committee or the
Cabinet.
